values.description:
* Added a theming plugin which allows you to customise the global qt stylesheets

    As part of this I made a small backwards compatible change to the plugin API.
    I also added a button to the preferences menu which appends example code for turning digital output buttons green (this button is here because the default behaviour is to leave the stylsesheet blank so as not to force an interface change onto users but I wanted to show how to structure stylesheets!).

* Updated the existing Plugins to support the latest version of the plugins API introduced by changeset: 6af58b9dc558

* Added link in theme plugin settings page to Qt stylesheet reference
values.title: Added theming support to BLACS

values.description:
Bugfix to queue processing:

Checking for abort/tab restarts while a shot is running is now done with a nonblocking call so that it does not prevent the 'done' signal from being received and acted upon, and does not introduce an additional 0.5 second delay *after* the done signal is received.

Previously, there was an unconditional 0.5 second delay checking for abort/restarts after the done signal was received, and there was a 50% chance of an additional zero to 0.5 second delay due to the 'done' signal arriving whilst the code was checking for abort/restart. This introduced a delay to shot processing of between 0.5 and 1 seconds, with an average of 0.625 seconds.

With this fix this part of the code no longer delays the end of a shot with waiting in this way - the only delay is actual code running not blocking `.get`() calls on queues.
values.title: Reduce average shot turnaround time by 0.625 seconds

summary.html:
Bugfix to queue processing:

Checking for abort/tab restarts while a shot is running is now done with a nonblocking call so that it does not prevent the 'done' signal from being received and acted upon, and does not introduce an additional 0.5 second delay after the done signal is received.

Previously, there was an unconditional 0.5 second delay checking for abort/restarts after the done signal was received, and there was a 50% chance of an additional zero to 0.5 second delay due to the 'done' signal arriving whilst the code was checking for abort/restart. This introduced a delay to shot processing of between 0.5 and 1 seconds, with an average of 0.625 seconds.

With this fix this part of the code no longer delays the end of a shot with waiting in this way - the only delay is actual code running not blocking .get() calls on queues.

values.description:
"Repeat last" functionality. The repeat button is still a check button, but when clicked, it pops up a menu asking which mode: repeat last or repeat all (or no repeat). It then is checked with its icon indicating which mode was selected, or unchecked if "no repeat" was selected.

I've confirmed that this setting is saved and loaded correctly when BLACS
is restarted.

This pull request does not rely on the other GUI pull request, so it is based off mainline prior to that, and the merges can happen in either order.

![blacs_repeat.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/dR5qxr/images/2305741711-blacs_repeat.png)
values.title: "Repeat last" functionality

values.description:
Functionality to delete repeated shots such that only a finite number of repeated shots are kept on disk at any one time. This prevents consuming disk space in the case of an experiment being "kept warm" by being left in repeat mode.

This functionality is implemented via a plugin, using a new callback for BLACS
plugins called "shot_complete". The shot deletion is done in a
separate thread so as not to slow down the experiment in the case of blocking
calls, and a zlock lock is acquired on the file prior to deletion
to minimise the harm done if say, a lyse routine is reading the file.

There is sensible behaviour in the case of the user decreasing the number of
shots to retain on disk. Shots that are queued for deletion are kept in a queue,
and when the number of shots to keep is decreased, shots are released from the
front of the queue (without being deleted) until the queue is the
same size as the number of shots now being retained. This means
that if the user set to keep 100 shots, and then goes ahead and runs a
hundred shots, if they then set it to keep 5 shots it won't delete
the 95 oldest shots in the deletion queue. Rather it will only delete the
most recent 5 (and not immediately - over the next 5 shots). I think this is
close to what people will expect when changing the number, and it errs on the
side of keeping shots.

If the added GUI elements seem like clutter to anyone, I'm sympathetic to perhaps adding a menu entry to the menu next to the "repeat" button, that would toggle whether this feature is active, or I'm open to any other suggestions.

This functionality is used all the time at JQI as the apparatuses are all of the type that need to be constantly running after they've warmed up.

Tooltip on the label and spinbox says what the feature does:

![blacs_delete_shots_1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/561283090-blacs_delete_shots_1.png)


Spinbox has a "special" entry: "all" which means no shots will be deleted. A small button resets it to this setting - any shots that were scheduled for deletion will not be deleted if you click this button:

![blacs_delete_shots_2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/2346199116-blacs_delete_shots_2.png)

Controls are disabled if not in repeat mode:

![blacs_delete_shots_3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/2512159685-blacs_delete_shots_3.png)
values.title: "delete repeated shots" functionality

values.description:
- Elided text in queue status, tab status bar, tab top bar (device name and connection) and tab label.
This prevents the GUI from jumping around while shots are running.

- Split queue status into two QLabels and set them separately - one for the actual status and one for the filename. Made status messages more concise so that they are less likely to be elided.

- Got rid of the splitter handle at the top of each tab when no error was visible.

- Device name and connection at top of tab now on one line as:
 device_name [connection]

- Shrank status bar of each tab

- Put queue controls in a box and made the box centred and not expanding

- Moved the delete-shots button next to the queue as a toolbutton with no text, and added an add-shots button there too. Connected the add-shots button to a file dialog to add shots (also connected the add shots menu item using the same QAction).

- Cleaned up analysis submission interface a bit. Added tooltips to each element to improve discoverability in the absence of labels.

- Reworked analysis submission logic to make it more responsive. "clear unsent shots" button used to just hang for many seconds before actually doing anything. Now things are responsive. Added a "retry now" button for retrying unsent shots, reduced the timeout time for connecting to lyse to 1 second instead of 2, and decreased the periodic connectivity checks to once every 10 seconds, instead of every second when not connected.

- Shrank connection table notification recompile button to just say "recompile" instead of "recompile connection table". The message next to it already makes it clear what's being recompiled.

- Made unexpected queue exceptions be raised in a thread so that they are still visible, even though the queue continues on.

- Used a QGridLayout for the queue part of the main interface to make things a bit better aligned.

(by the way, I've checked the option "close feature2 after the pull request is merged". When merging, bitbucket gives the merger the option of changing this to not close the branch. Please do close the branch. Perhaps counterintuitively, re-using branches like I'm doing is easier if they are closed every time.)

![blacs_elision.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/1351085268-blacs_elision.png)
values.title: Prevent GUI from jumping around, pixel saving, analysis submission improvements

values.description:
The buttons in BLACS look pretty silly being borderless when there is no theme applied. So there should either be a default theme or disabling of the borderlessness for buttons within tabs. I prefer the option of setting a default theme, so I've made the green theme be pre-set in the theming plugin if there is not already a stylesheet saved. I also changed the theme to make the buttons smaller.

- Make green theme default. Not by setting it in BLACS proper, merely by making it the theming plugin's default stylesheet if there is not one set. That means people updating who are already using a custom stylesheet will not see the changes unless they delete their stylesheet and replace it and click the "append example" button.

- Shrank 'green theme' font and padding in buttons.

- Darker text on unchecked buttons to improve readability at smaller font size.

Before:

![blacs_buttons_before.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/344883807-blacs_buttons_before.png)

After:

![blacs_buttons_after.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/1947915232-blacs_buttons_after.png)
values.title: Smaller green buttons, and make theme default

values.description:
This pull request along with it's sister pull requests introduces qtutil's new abstraction layer for Qt. This abstraction layer is supposed to act like PyQt5. A few adjustments needed to be made so things don't break.

This pull request should also bring PyQt5 compatibility but this should be experimental at first so reviewing should not include this as a criterium for approval. (This has been discussed [here](https://pstarkey.github.io/bitbucket-archive/#!/pull-requests/1/pyqt5/diff#comment-41775691))

To test this one needs to also pull from my qtutils repo [here](https://bitbucket.org/PhyNerd/qtutils/).
values.title: qtutils 2.0.0 support and experimental PyQt5 support

values.title: Plugin Tabs

summary.html:
This adds the ability for plugins to spawn Tabs.

A plugin can spawn a tab by having a get_tab_classes(self) function. This function should return a dict of Tab classes, where the key should be the name of the Tab.

Plugin tabs should inherit from the PluginTab class in blacs.tab_base_classes. This class provides some basic functionality a tab in BLACS currently needs. Also this allows for the Plugin tabs to use get_save_data to store and restore_save_data to restore data that they might want to save. The initialization of the GUI should be implemented in a function called initialise_GUI, that automatically gets called in the constructor.

To visually distinguish plugin tabs from devices their text is blue and they have a different icon.

Here is example code for a basic tab with a button that raises a exception on click:

from blacs.tab_base_classes import PluginTab
from qtutils.qt.QtWidgets import *

class Plugin(object):
    def __init__(self, initial_settings):
        self.menu = None
        self.notifications = {}
        self.BLACS = None
        self.tabs = {}

    def get_menu_class(self):
        return None

    def get_notification_classes(self):
        return []

    def get_setting_classes(self):
        return []

    def get_callbacks(self):
        return {}

    def set_menu_instance(self, menu):
        self.menu = menu

    def set_notification_instances(self, notifications):
        self.notifications = notifications

    def plugin_setup_complete(self, BLACS):
        self.BLACS = BLACS

    def get_tab_classes(self):
        return {'hallo': TestTab}

    def tabs_created(self, tabs_dict):
        self.tabs = tabs_dict

    def get_save_data(self):
        return {}

    def close(self):
        pass


class TestTab(PluginTab):
    def initialise_GUI(self):
        self.layout = self.get_tab_layout()

        self.foobutton = QPushButton('Error')
        self.foobutton.clicked.connect(self.test_abc)

        self.layout.addWidget(self.foobutton)

    def test_abc(self, *args):
        raise Exception('test')

    def get_save_data(self):
        return {}

    def restore_save_data(self,data):
        return

values.description:
The goal of this pull request is to make analog in data visible in the BLACS front panel while in manual mode.

This adds a [Broker/Forwarder](http://learning-0mq-with-pyzmq.readthedocs.io/en/latest/pyzmq/devices/forwarder.html) to BLACS that forwards acquired data from the acquisition workers to any app that might want that data via a publish/subscribe model.
 
It also adds the ability for tabs to add [analog in widgets](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/27/analogin/diff#comment-43694653).(this is mostly copy paste from analog out) Each tab (that has analog in widgets) also gets a thread checking for new data and updating the widgets.

values.description:
This adds ```analysis_filter``` callbacks to the Plugins API. 

A ```analysis_filter``` is passed a filepath of the h5file that is about to be send to analysis. If the ```analysis_filter``` returns True this shot will not be sent to analysis any other or no return value will not have any effect.

The reasoning for this new callback is that in our lab we want to rerun the first shot of each sequence before sending it to analysis. This needs to be done because we use the end of the last experiment to prepare the MOT for the next one to make use of the dead time in between shots. MOT parameters might vary between different sequences and pauses between sequences make the first shot have a much bigger MOT so the first shot need to be run twice.
values.title: Analysis filters

values.description:
This should make BLACS run under Python 3 in a backwards compatible way. Most changes are trivial.

A few adjustments had to be made to the front panel settings and connectiontable as the numpy arrays stored in the hdf5 files have byte strings that need to be converted.

Also the queue.py file had to be renamed due to the name collision with the queue module in Python3.

* Added future import to all files
* Python3 adjustments
* ~~made connectiontable handle bytestrings better~~
* ~~renamed queue.py to experiment\_queue.py to resolve bug, where instead of the queue module blacs.queue would be loaded by other modules~~
* ~~cleaner solution to the dtypes problem~~
* ~~renamed blacs\_queue to the more fiting experiment\_queue~~

To test this the qtutils Python3 changes must have been made before.

summary.html:
This should make BLACS run under Python 3 in a backwards compatible way. Most changes are trivial.

A few adjustments had to be made to the front panel settings and connectiontable as the numpy arrays stored in the hdf5 files have byte strings that need to be converted.

Also the queue.py file had to be renamed due to the name collision with the queue module in Python3.

  • Added future import to all files
  • Python3 adjustments
  • made connectiontable handle bytestrings better
  • renamed queue.py to experiment_queue.py to resolve bug, where instead of the queue module blacs.queue would be loaded by other modules
  • cleaner solution to the dtypes problem
  • renamed blacs_queue to the more fiting experiment_queue

To test this the qtutils Python3 changes must have been made before.

values.description:
The goal of this pull request is to add the ability to activated/deactivate plugins without needing to remove them form the plugins folder.

This is achieved by a simple modification to the `BLACS.plugins` module. It now check if a plugin is activated in the labconfig or not before adding it to the `modules` dict. The default setting for new plugins is active as I suspect new plugin will be added on purpose rather than accidentally.

To make the state of plugins user editable it is stored in the Labconfig file in a newly created section `BLACS/plugins`. 

This pull request should be inline with the result of the discussion that was held over at [Pull requests #9](#!/labscript_suite/blacs/pull-requests/9/delete-repeated-shots-functionality/diff).
values.title: Plugin Management

summary.html:
The goal of this pull request is to add the ability to activated/deactivate plugins without needing to remove them form the plugins folder.

This is achieved by a simple modification to the BLACS.plugins module. It now check if a plugin is activated in the labconfig or not before adding it to the modules dict. The default setting for new plugins is active as I suspect new plugin will be added on purpose rather than accidentally.

To make the state of plugins user editable it is stored in the Labconfig file in a newly created section BLACS/plugins.

This pull request should be inline with the result of the discussion that was held over at Pull requests #9.

values.description:
Python3 has a standard library named queue which replaces Queue. 

There are a lot of import problems that we will need to handle if we keep the naming of queue.py. 

To prevent future problems this pull request renames queue.py to experiment\_queue.py.

The file content remains unchanged.

values.description:
This Pull request adds a new 'shot\_ignore\_repeat' callback to the plugin system. This new callback gives plugins the ability to keep certain shots from being repeated.

In our lab we use this in a keep warm plugin which automatically prepends a keep warm shot to the queue if it should be empty or if our lab watchdog says something went wrong. The shot file is then cleaned \(just like repeats\) after the shot is done and prepended to the queue \(if needed\). If the repeat all mode is active this leads to a queue with a lot of repetitions piling up at its end. This callback/filter allows to prevent this behavior.
values.title: Repeat Filter Callback

values.description:
Don't use `__file__` to infer the location of the script - it is unreliable due to relative paths and the possibility of someone having called `os.chdir()`.

Also don't call `os.chdir()`, and use absolute paths for everything.

I converted all the relative paths I knew about to absolute ones, and got all uses of `__file__`, but I may have missed some. Basic testing doesn't throw any file-not-found errors when running BLACS from a different directory.
values.title: Absolute imports, and don't use __file__

values.description:
This adds a button to show a terminal for each device showing its logging output and any printlines etc.

This makes it easier to debug devices, as well as making very basic devices where they just say on the terminal what they're doing instead of writing GUI code to do so. Lincoln was mentioning that this is something that would be desirable given the number of single-purpose scripts being written that really ought to be device tabs but that nobody really cares to write a GUI for.

This does mean that per-device logging output will not be present in the terminal if running BLACS from the terminal - only logging output from the main process. However, the BLACS log file will still contain logging from all processes.

If this is considered too big a drawback, I can add an option to OutputBox to make it duplicate any output it receives to the stdout/stderr of the current process.

Terminal visibility and splitter size is saved and loaded to the BLACS settings file. This required me to introduce `DeviceTab.get_builtin_save_data()` and `DeviceTab.restore_builtin_save_data()` since `get_save_data` and `restore_save_data` are not required to call the base class implementation, so I could not put it there. But it stores the settings in the same dict (with names prefixed by an underscore).

This change depends on [labscript_utils pull request 40](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/40/), otherwise the subprocesses have stdout set to devnull and won't produce any output.

Screenshot (button is up the top next to the restart button):

![blacs_terminal.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/3533854408-blacs_terminal.png)
values.title: Worker terminals

values.description:
Shrink compile and restart window, make it properly resizable, and give it a title.

Russ pointed out that the compile and restart window was too big for some small screens, hiding the dialog buttons. Even if the window manager (or the user) resizes the window to fit, the widgets were fixed in-place as the QDialog was not laid out properly - shrinking the window would just obscure the buttons and not actually shrink the output box.

This PR makes the window smaller, gives it a meaningful title (was previously '__main__.py') and lays it out so that the widgets actually resize with the window.

![blacs_cns.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/4271415261-blacs_cns.png)
values.title: Compile and restart fixes

values.description:
Move 'clear queue' button to the side of the queue where the 'add' and 'remove' buttons are.


This is  partly for consistency, since it makes sense to put this button next to the 'delete selection' button, but also because the number of buttons above the queue limits how small you can make the queue horizontally, so this allows the GUI to be more compact.



Before:

![blacs-before.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/3741973950-blacs-before.png)

After:

![blacs-after.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/3008455194-blacs-after.png)


Adding @PhyNerd as a reviewer since he added the button in the first place, so opinions welcome.

values.description:
Made use of ConnectionTable's 'exceptions\_in\_thread' keyword.

This in combination with a pull request over at labscript\_utils will fix a bug which causes BLACS to not start if a queued experiment file doesn’t exists.

values.description:
We now have a new method in the Tab base class called `get_all_save_data()` which collates the save data from `Tab.get_builtin_save_data` and the `get_save_data` method of a subclass \(if it exists\). We also fix a bug which causes blacs to crash on exit if the return value of `get_save_data()` was not a dictionary. We also change the order in which the dictionary gets updated so that subclasses can override the restore behaviour of the worker terminal if they wish \(but it's discouraged via the use of the underscore prepending the dictionary keys\). The front panel settings saving code is also now simplified to make use of these changes!

This fixes issue #47 and results in a bump of the patch version to 2.3.1

‌

@PhyNerd  This will require an update to your plugin tabs pull request #18 to include an equivalent of the `get_all_save_data` method \(I suggest just copy/pasting what I have done here, it should work provided you have `self.logger`\).

‌
values.title: Fixed a bug where the save data for the console was not being stored on tab restart

values.description:
Deserialise transition_to_manual of devices at the end of a shot.

This fixes the bug where a device blocking until the waits monitor has finished processing waits may deadlock because the two are not actually happening in parallel. This has limited experiments to only using a single analog input device.

It also provides a potential speedup for all experiments.

I am not 100% happy with the cleanness of this code, but it is in line with how the parallelised transition_to_buffered works. I want to resist refactoring the queue manager's main loop into separate functions (I think this would make it much clearer what the responsibilities of each segment are), because this issue is a problem in a lab using the Spielman fork so I want to keep it easily mergable with a version of BLACS that diverged some time ago, which refactoring would make difficult. So I'd like to revisit this at some point, but this PR solves the immediate issue.

I've done basic testing but more would be prudent.
values.title: Deserialise transition_to_manual

values.description:
Adds basic support for Image output types \(SLMs, DMDs etc\).

Originally written by @pstarkey in the context of a static SLM with multiple sub-images, though this was never fully implemented. More recently I’ve used this to implement a DMD device which can play back sequences of images, which has been operational in our lab for over a year. Recent updates have been merged in from default and tested in the lab.
values.title: Add basic support for Image output types

values.description:
Added priorities for plugin callbacks. Plugin callbacks may now be decorated with the decorator `blacs.plugins.callback(priority=<number>)`, and those with the lowest number for their priority will be called first. The defauly priority is 10, which will be used if no priority is specified or if a callback does not use this decorator. Because it is optional, this change is backward compatible with existing callbacks, which will work unmodified. I have not added the decorator to any of the callbacks of the plugins shipped with BLACS.

This functionality was implemented by defining a Callback class in blacs.plugins
that has an attribute for the priority, but is also a callable, and so can be
just called as normal if the priority is not relevant.

Moved `get_callbacks()` from `blacs.experiment_queue` into `blacs.plugins`, and
modified it to return callbacks in order of priority. Removed the `inmain`
decorator from it since it should not normally need to touch the GUI - if a
plugin needs to touch the GUI to get callbacks for whatever reason, it can call
`inmain()` itself.

Replaced the remaining code in the
queue manager that manually looked through plugins for callbacks with
a call to get_callbacks.

This is so that I can make a plugin with a callback for 'shot_complete', which
delays the start of the next shot. This callback should run last if there are
other callbacks, necessitating priorities of some sort.
values.title: Plugin callback priorities

summary.html:
Added priorities for plugin callbacks. Plugin callbacks may now be decorated with the decorator blacs.plugins.callback(priority=<number>), and those with the lowest number for their priority will be called first. The defauly priority is 10, which will be used if no priority is specified or if a callback does not use this decorator. Because it is optional, this change is backward compatible with existing callbacks, which will work unmodified. I have not added the decorator to any of the callbacks of the plugins shipped with BLACS.

This functionality was implemented by defining a Callback class in blacs.plugins that has an attribute for the priority, but is also a callable, and so can be just called as normal if the priority is not relevant.

Moved get_callbacks() from blacs.experiment_queue into blacs.plugins, and modified it to return callbacks in order of priority. Removed the inmain decorator from it since it should not normally need to touch the GUI - if a plugin needs to touch the GUI to get callbacks for whatever reason, it can call inmain() itself.

Replaced the remaining code in the queue manager that manually looked through plugins for callbacks with a call to get_callbacks.

This is so that I can make a plugin with a callback for 'shot_complete', which delays the start of the next shot. This callback should run last if there are other callbacks, necessitating priorities of some sort.

values.description:
Added a plugin that allows one to impose a fixed interval between the beginning of
subsequent shots. This is a feature present in the Spielman fork, and is used to ensure that the experiment that needs to be 'kept warm' can be put in an equilibrium state in which some process runs with a fixed duty cycle despite varying shot durations. For us this is UV desorption or rubidium during MOT loading. To keep a consistent pressure in the MOT cell during this state from one shot to the next, it's important that the UV is on a fixed fraction of the time.

This can be achieved by having BLACS wait before running the next shot, leaving a configurable buffer of time so that it can run shots at a fixed interval despite the shots having small variations in duration (for science reasons or software timing differences or otherwise).

Although there is still software timing differences after this point, I decided to insert the delay just before transition_to_buffered is called on all devices. This is because transition_to_buffered may cause some devices to start outputting their initial instructions, which may be undesirable.

here's what it looks like:

![blacs_fixed_plugin.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/1175914126-blacs_fixed_plugin.png)

If the interval is set to zero, it instead displays 'none', and runs shots as they come without trying to impose a fixed interval. If shots take too long such that the interval is not able to be achieved, an error icon is displayed, but BLACS continues to run shots.

Whilst waiting, the plugin attaches an additional callback to the abort button, so that it will stop waiting if the abort button is clicked.
values.title: Fixed shot interval

![blacs_fixed_plugin.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9pKE7ad/images/1175914126-blacs_fixed_plugin.png)

summary.html:
Added a plugin that allows one to impose a fixed interval between the beginning of subsequent shots. This is a feature present in the Spielman fork, and is used to ensure that the experiment that needs to be 'kept warm' can be put in an equilibrium state in which some process runs with a fixed duty cycle despite varying shot durations. For us this is UV desorption or rubidium during MOT loading. To keep a consistent pressure in the MOT cell during this state from one shot to the next, it's important that the UV is on a fixed fraction of the time.

This can be achieved by having BLACS wait before running the next shot, leaving a configurable buffer of time so that it can run shots at a fixed interval despite the shots having small variations in duration (for science reasons or software timing differences or otherwise).

Although there is still software timing differences after this point, I decided to insert the delay just before transition_to_buffered is called on all devices. This is because transition_to_buffered may cause some devices to start outputting their initial instructions, which may be undesirable.

here's what it looks like:

If the interval is set to zero, it instead displays 'none', and runs shots as they come without trying to impose a fixed interval. If shots take too long such that the interval is not able to be achieved, an error icon is displayed, but BLACS continues to run shots.

Whilst waiting, the plugin attaches an additional callback to the abort button, so that it will stop waiting if the abort button is clicked.
